<p><strong>In earlier research</strong> on solving the net-zero equation,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="25078f84-29c5-4811-9dd4-0bb08e6f5aea"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="25078f84-29c5-4811-9dd4-0bb08e6f5aea" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For more, see “<a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/solving-the-net-zero-equation-nine-requirements-for-a-more-orderly-transition">Solving the net-zero equation: Nine requirements for a more orderly transition</a>,” McKinsey, October 27, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> we described the nine key requirements we believe must be met for an orderly energy transition. These fall into three broad categories: physical building blocks; economic and societal adjustments; and governance, institutions, and commitments. This article focuses on the first area, particularly on the ability to create at-scale supply chains and support infrastructure for key decarbonization technologies.</p>

data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body">This article is a collaborative effort by Stathia Bampinioti, <a href="/our-people/harald-bauer">Harald Bauer</a>, Nadia Christakou, Luigi Gigliotti, Emil Hosius, Friederike Liebach, <a href="/our-people/lorenzo-moavero-milanesi">Lorenzo Moavero Milanesi</a>, <a href="/our-people/humayun-tai">Humayun Tai</a>, and <a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b1f1fbafa-dff3-4c0a-8266-79f3ad6e78c4%7d%40en">Raffael Winter</a>, representing views from McKinsey’s Advanced Industries and Electric Power & Natural Gas Practices.</div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The energy transition is already well under way in Europe, but it will need to accelerate significantly to meet the European Union’s Fit for 55 targets and deliver on REPowerEU, an energy security action plan developed in response to events in Ukraine.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f7e63996-8ef9-45e6-9b6f-c456e2da12cd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f7e63996-8ef9-45e6-9b6f-c456e2da12cd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Fit for 55,” European Council, June 30, 2022; “REPowerEU Plan,” European Council, May 18, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> One measure in the REPowerEU plan, for example, mandates the installation of 320 gigawatts (GW) of new solar photovoltaics (PVs) by 2025 and 600 GW by 2030. Meeting this goal will require a threefold to fivefold increase in the solar PV installation rate.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>Increased (and increasing) demand for the technologies that enable decarbonization—such as electrification technologies across industrial processes, buildings, power supply, and the mobility industry—creates many knock-on opportunities. Companies at each step of the affected value chain have the opportunity to benefit, as we discussed in a recent article focused on electrification.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2929353f-b4ec-41fe-a7eb-3852b437e470"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2929353f-b4ec-41fe-a7eb-3852b437e470" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For more, see “<a href="/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/unlocking-opportunities-from-industrial-electrification">Unlocking opportunities from industrial electrification</a>,” McKinsey, July 18, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Those looking to take advantage of these opportunities will need to be cognizant of a number of risks and act to avoid them. Avoiding bottlenecks in already-stretched supply chains is particularly important, especially in the context of recent geopolitical events; bottlenecks create risks around volume shortages, price volatility, geographical-sourcing dependency, long lead times, and issues with quality. These risks can affect all key energy transition technologies and every step of the supply chain. Particular challenges are expected around the procurement of raw materials, manufacturing of components, and availability of labor for construction and installation.</p>
<p>Businesses and other key stakeholders looking to shore up supply chain resilience for an orderly energy transition can take a range of mitigation actions. Fast and decisive action to analyze and strengthen supply chains and a willingness to invest judiciously can help position Europe and its businesses to capture the substantial opportunities of an orderly energy transition. A lack of action will increase the risk that Europe may fall behind in achieving its important, ambitious energy goals—or even miss out on these opportunities entirely.</p>
<h2>The energy transition is under way, and the pace of decarbonization will only increase</h2>
<p>The drive toward decarbonization, increasing cost competitiveness, and geopolitical considerations have further accelerated the energy transition and significantly increased the pace of electrification.</p>
<p>But the rate of decarbonization will need to more than triple to meet the European Union’s Fit for 55 target of a 55 percent emissions reduction from 1990 levels by 2030.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="39ad39d3-f68b-492d-8b81-c0237a1c11e5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="39ad39d3-f68b-492d-8b81-c0237a1c11e5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“EU greenhouse gas emissions fell in 2019 to the lowest level in three decades,” European Commission, November 30, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> There will need to be a dramatic shift toward renewables in power supply and toward electrification technologies in demand.</p>
<p>These top-level targets have profound implications for the products and technologies that enable electrification and thus decarbonization. Renewable-energy sources (RES), for example, will need to constitute 70 percent of the generation mix by 2030.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="936b825c-f8fd-4780-9ba8-50af433a92a2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="936b825c-f8fd-4780-9ba8-50af433a92a2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/global-energy-perspective-2022"><em>Global Energy Perspective 2022</em></a>, Achieved Commitments scenario, McKinsey, April 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Increased demand for electricity will further complicate the transition.</p>
<p>The result of these shifts will be a strong and growing demand for electrification-enabling technologies. These technologies include wind, solar PV, and battery storage in the power industry; heat pumps for buildings and industrial processes; and batteries and charging infrastructure for the mobility sector, to name just a few. This burgeoning demand will be synchronized along the entire value chain, from raw and processed materials and manufacturing of components and assemblies all the way to logistics and construction.</p>
<h2>Supply chains are facing significant—and growing—challenges</h2>
<p>Supply chains for key energy transition technologies are already stretched, and recent geopolitical events have further exacerbated the situation. The global pandemic disrupted supply chains, resulting in multiple-month production halts while major supplier countries went into lockdown.</p>
<p>For example, more than two years into the pandemic, the gap between chip supply and demand has widened across all semiconductor-enabled products. This semiconductor shortage will likely persist in selected technology nodes for the next three to five years. For mature node sizes, for example, shortages are expected to persist until 2026.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="31645b33-03b0-4eee-9dd8-79fe37a2f935"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="31645b33-03b0-4eee-9dd8-79fe37a2f935" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ondrej Burkacky, Johannes Deichmann, Philipp Pfingstag, and Julia Werra, “<a href="/industries/semiconductors/our-insights/semiconductor-shortage-how-the-automotive-industry-can-succeed">Semiconductor shortage: How the automotive industry can succeed</a>,” McKinsey, June 10, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>More recently, the war in Ukraine has disrupted the supply of oil and gas and has driven many European countries to make decisions that will have a long-term impact on where and how they source their energy supply. There have also been disruptions around other key raw materials for which Russia and Ukraine are key suppliers. For example, 43 percent of the global production of palladium is sourced from Russia, 33 percent of global semifinished steel imports are supplied by Russia or Ukraine, and 17 percent of global class 1 nickel is produced in Russia.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9b528ab1-ccfe-4a31-83ff-99285af47696"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9b528ab1-ccfe-4a31-83ff-99285af47696" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Share of global production and rank for selected minerals and metals in Russia, 2020,” IEA, last updated May 20, 2022; “List of exporters for semi-finished products of iron or non-alloy steel,” Trade Map, International Trade Centre (ITC), accessed September 10, 2022; McKinsey MineSpans.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>These events and trends could amplify five risk areas related to supply chains: volume shortage, price volatility, geographical-sourcing dependency, long lead times, and issues with quality (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/building%20resilient%20supply%20chains%20for%20the%20european%20energy%20transition/svgz-buildingsupplychainseurope-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Building resilient supply chains for the European energy transition" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/building%20resilient%20supply%20chains%20for%20the%20european%20energy%20transition/svgz-buildingsupplychainseurope-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>Key industry players are increasingly aware of the need to act—and many have already started to do so. In 2022, for example, the World Economic Forum noted the risk of choke points in the supply of commodities such as lithium and copper and advocated for global standards as well as increased innovation to boost supply diversity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7a1fd095-f59b-4e6c-a8d7-679b7227fb01"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7a1fd095-f59b-4e6c-a8d7-679b7227fb01" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Joisa Saraiva and David G. Victor, “Rethinking global supply chains for the energy transition,” World Economic Forum, January 31, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> In September 2021, the European Raw Materials Alliance introduced a plan calling for governments and manufacturers to support mining and processing through a mix of subsidies and sales quotas.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f61d9b19-51f8-4e7b-8cb0-f38fa8eb58b0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f61d9b19-51f8-4e7b-8cb0-f38fa8eb58b0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Elisabeth Behrmann, “EU makes $2 billion push to curb reliance on China’s rare earths,” <em>Bloomberg</em>, September 30, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h2>Risks exist along each step of the supply chain</h2>
<p>Supply chain risks can affect procurement, manufacturing, logistics, and construction. These risks have the potential to cause serious disruption for all key energy transition technologies (Exhibit 2). For a deep dive on how supply chain risks threaten every step of the value chain for heat pumps, see sidebar, “Vulnerabilities in the heat pump supply chain.”</p>

<p>Individual risk profiles and the actions needed to minimize them vary for each step of the value chain, with particular challenges expected in raw materials, components, and labor.</p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Vulnerabilities in the heat pump supply chain</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Heat pumps can be used</strong> to electrify both space and water heating in the residential- and commercial-buildings sector, where they replace gas and oil boilers. They can also be used to electrify industrial processes such as in the chemicals, pulp and paper, and food and beverage industries.</p>
<p>Historically, heat pumps have been significantly more expensive than alternatives in terms of total cost of ownership. At 2019 fuel prices, for example, the cost of heating an average German residential dwelling was about 50 percent higher with air-to-water heat pumps than with a condensing gas boiler.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8d8e92c5-2197-4dfb-ad9d-0c57f6a0a696"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8d8e92c5-2197-4dfb-ad9d-0c57f6a0a696" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Are renewable heating options cost-competitive with fossil fuels in the residential sector?,” IEA, December 1, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> However, rising commodity prices and direct subsidies are rendering these pumps increasingly cost competitive. In addition, carbon taxes and policies will further encourage the installation of heat pumps, which are both a short-term lever to reduce European dependency on Russian oil and gas and a key longer-term decarbonization lever.</p>
<p>As a result, the European Commission has set a target to double the rate of deployment of heat pumps over the next five years. <span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="68ee08ac-cc8c-4d1e-b413-e6bb59566a49"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="68ee08ac-cc8c-4d1e-b413-e6bb59566a49" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Communication from the Commission to the European Parliament, the European Council, the Council, the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions,” European Commission, May 18, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> An analysis of heat pump supply chains, however, reveals a number of potential vulnerabilities:</p>
<p><em><strong>Procurement of raw and processed material.</strong></em> Steel and copper are among the key raw materials for the creation of heat pumps. While steel production will likely not face bottlenecks in supply, increased demand for green steel and increasing energy prices might significantly drive up steel prices. There will also likely be a near-term undersupply of copper. Demand will increase as a result of grid expansion, increasing renewable energy, and the adoption of electric vehicles (EVs), while supply will be limited by aging mining assets and weak project pipelines.</p>
<p><em><strong>Component manufacturing.</strong></em> While components such as fans and valves are highly commoditized, and therefore no sourcing constraints are expected, inverters and electrical components may fall victim to the semiconductor bottleneck.</p>
<p><em><strong>Components assembly.</strong></em> Increased use can increase the output of existing assembly lines, but there are high barriers to entry for new players in the heat pump market; complex systems and licensing requirements in certain cases result in a lead time of up to 12 months to open new plants.</p>
<p><em><strong>Construction and labor.</strong></em> While increasing worker shifts can provide some labor scale-up flexibility, labor shortages might slow down the uptake of heat pumps. To meet governmental targets, for example, the United Kingdom will need to add 5,000 to 7,000 heat pump installers per year from 2025 until 2035.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="94aee615-2dc0-4cfa-b563-ec974a3c7f0e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="94aee615-2dc0-4cfa-b563-ec974a3c7f0e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Shortage of trained heat pump installers could set back net zero,” Nesta, July 7, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Furthermore, the ability to retrofit heat pumps into existing buildings is restricted by space limitations in urban housing and bureaucratic hurdles, such as the need for owner communities’ approval and preservation orders.</p>
<p>Enabling strong heat pump uptake may therefore require businesses and other relevant stakeholders to consider the following actions:</p>
<ul>
<li>Advocate for supportive policies (including subsidies and carbon taxes), launch awareness campaigns to increase local demand, and engage in large-scale skilling and reskilling efforts for technicians.</li>
<li>Make corporate commitments in commercial real estate to accelerate the adoption of heat pumps in stakeholders’ building portfolios.</li>
<li>Create innovative designs to enable the retrofitting of buildings and allow for heat pump installation in small urban apartments.</li>
<li>Scale up assembly-line production capacity with a focus on automated-manufacturing practices.</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<h3>Procurement of raw and processed materials</h3>
<p>The main supply chain risks that are likely to affect raw materials are supply shortages and geographical-sourcing dependency.</p>
<p>These risks will be particularly severe for rare-earth materials. Neodymium and praseodymium, for example, are key components of the permanent magnets used in wind power and electric vehicles (EVs) and will see a surge in demand in the coming years. Substitution options are limited, which may create risks in the future because the industry is highly dependent on China’s refining capacity. Recycling will therefore be a key focus area, but based on expected capacity growth plans, we nevertheless predict an undersupply of 50 to 60 percent in 2030, leading to significant price spikes.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9d903cb2-e074-4468-94e9-24568e7dcd3c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9d903cb2-e074-4468-94e9-24568e7dcd3c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Dolf Gielen, “Engineering is key to easing the supply crunch of critical materials for clean energy,” Engineering for Change, October 20, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Other raw materials will also be affected. For example, the energy transition and electrification will significantly increase demand for metals such as nickel, lithium, cobalt, aluminum, and copper. Demand is already rising, which has driven price increases (Exhibit 3). We expect that opportunities for increasing supply, recycling, and substitution will maintain a relative equilibrium between supply and demand for aluminum, copper, and cobalt, but we expect to see supply shortages of class 1 nickel and lithium in 2025.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/building%20resilient%20supply%20chains%20for%20the%20european%20energy%20transition/svgz-buildingsupplychainseurope-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Building resilient supply chains for the European energy transition" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/building%20resilient%20supply%20chains%20for%20the%20european%20energy%20transition/svgz-buildingsupplychainseurope-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>Component manufacturing and assembly</h3>
<p>Increased demand for assets will increase demand for components, but the share of components that are made in Europe is decreasing. Dependency on non-EU countries for the sourcing of key components could therefore become a major risk, particularly for solar PV, batteries, and power electronics.</p>
<p>China is (and is set to remain) the dominant producer along the value chain; it currently provides more than 70 percent of solar-cell and module components and 66 percent of finished lithium batteries.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bfd20fab-10cb-4261-8717-006358e360a3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bfd20fab-10cb-4261-8717-006358e360a3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Critical raw materials for strategic technologies and sectors in the EU,” European Commission, September 3, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Most semiconductors are also produced in Asia—22 percent in China, 19 percent in Taiwan, 17 percent in Korea, and 16 percent in Japan—with France and Germany together accounting for only 5 percent of global front-end production.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f427b19f-425a-45de-a8c2-7f43ac3d992c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f427b19f-425a-45de-a8c2-7f43ac3d992c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“World Fab Forecast,” SEMI, Q4 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The steady decrease in the number of domestic EU production facilities for many components has mainly been driven by commoditization, which has led to competition based predominantly on price with few opportunities for product differentiation. European companies will struggle to compete on price; solar PV module costs are currently 20 to 35 percent higher in Europe than in China, primarily driven by higher costs for labor, materials, and CO<sub>2</sub>.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5746d9aa-f800-43e6-ab3d-ec3df520c216"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5746d9aa-f800-43e6-ab3d-ec3df520c216" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/global-energy-perspective-2022"><em>Global Energy Perspective 2022</em></a>; McKinsey analysis.</span></span></span></a></span> Scaling the local manufacturing ecosystem could decrease price differences by eight to 17 percentage points, but this will take at least three to five years (Exhibit 4).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/building%20resilient%20supply%20chains%20for%20the%20european%20energy%20transition/svgz-buildingsupplychainseurope-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Building resilient supply chains for the European energy transition" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/building%20resilient%20supply%20chains%20for%20the%20european%20energy%20transition/svgz-buildingsupplychainseurope-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Western turbine manufacturers dominate the European market for wind power. In the past several years, however, Western OEMs have faced profitability issues due to lower-than-expected build-out and increased price competition driven by a shift to purely cost-driven tender design in many countries. As a result, many European countries—including Denmark, Germany, and Spain—have experienced job losses and factory closures.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="549ca7be-989b-4d76-a0d8-2e84762b1f17"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="549ca7be-989b-4d76-a0d8-2e84762b1f17" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Maz Plechinger, “Nordex to lay off a fifth of staff in Germany,” <em>EnergyWatch</em>, March 1, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>More recently, rising commodity prices have further eroded profitability. Many OEMs are fully exposed to increasing prices, resulting in double-digit negative EBIT margins for some European OEMs in the first quarter of 2022.</p>
<p>The Western world should build on learnings from the solar industry and strive to maintain a strong domestic industry and supply chain. As an example, refining tender designs to also incorporate more qualitative criteria—such as sustainability, carbon footprints, and system integration—could help ease pressure on the wind supply chain.</p>
<h3>Logistics</h3>
<p>There are also risks to an orderly energy transition related to the transportation of key technologies to the location of installation. These risks generally manifest as volume shortages.</p>
<p>Logistics is likely to become increasingly challenging in offshore wind. Increases in both capacity installation and, as a result of rapid technological advancement, turbine size are likely to lead to a shortage of appropriate installation vessels starting in 2025. We project that in 2026, about three GW of planned capacity will not be able to be installed because of the undersupply, and the size of this gap will increase over time.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="924f071f-f2ef-4dfd-8743-914744f2b766"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="924f071f-f2ef-4dfd-8743-914744f2b766" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/global-energy-perspective-2022"><em>Global Energy Perspective 2022</em></a>, Achieved Commitments Scenario; “Installation Vessel Supply and Demand Q1 2022,” 4C Offshore, April 2022; McKinsey analysis.</span></span></span></a></span> The lead time for supersized installation vessels is considerable, which means that without prompt action, this mismatch between supply and demand is likely to be of considerable duration.</p>
<h3>Construction and labor</h3>
<p>Skilled labor to work on RES in the European Union is already scarce today, and employers experience a high level of competition from adjacent sectors. In 2019, for example, there were 1.8 job vacancies in Germany for every unemployed energy technician.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7eeb6a50-1964-4458-8b6f-fb4a4f9c4e6c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7eeb6a50-1964-4458-8b6f-fb4a4f9c4e6c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Bottleneck Analysis,” Federal Employment Agency, December 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>This labor scarcity will get significantly worse: the demand for blue- and white-collar workers to develop and construct wind and solar assets in the European Union, for example, is expected to increase by a factor of between three and four by 2030 (Exhibit 5).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a2dbeaec-b5e8-4455-b8be-8ca9c39c33b9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a2dbeaec-b5e8-4455-b8be-8ca9c39c33b9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Renewable energy benefits: Measuring the economics</em>, IRENA, January 2016; <a href="/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/global-energy-perspective-2022"><em>Global Energy Perspective 2022</em></a>, Achieved Commitments Scenario.</span></span></span></a></span> Labor shortages will be further exacerbated by an increasing demand for workers to operate and maintain these wind and solar projects; the lack of technicians is expected to be a particular pain point.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/building%20resilient%20supply%20chains%20for%20the%20european%20energy%20transition/svgz-buildingsupplychainseurope-ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Building resilient supply chains for the European energy transition" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/building%20resilient%20supply%20chains%20for%20the%20european%20energy%20transition/svgz-buildingsupplychainseurope-ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h2>Stakeholders can act to minimize supply chain risks—and seize the opportunities</h2>
<p>Businesses and other relevant stakeholders could take a range of mitigation actions to guard against supply chain risks. These actions are not just about mitigating risk, however: building supply chain resilience can also be an opportunity and a catalyst for collaboration and partnerships, as well as a driver of innovation—for example, to replace materials and increase productivity.</p>
<h3>Potential actions for businesses</h3>
<p>The right next steps will vary by the type and the specifics of individual businesses, but the following resilience-boosting actions can be beneficial to businesses along the supply chain:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Diversify and localize supply chains</em> for critical raw materials and components across multiple suppliers and geographies.</li>
    <li><em>Explore opportunities for cross-industry pooled procurement</em> of raw materials.</li>
    <li><em>Invest in recycling, innovation, and research around substitutes</em> for critical materials.</li>
    <li><em>Explore opportunities for vertical integration</em> to secure critical raw materials and decrease price volatility, either through alliances and partnerships or through targeted acquisitions.</li>
    <li><em>Optimize procurement strategies</em> by targeting long-term supply agreements or developing streaming agreements with advance lump-sum payments for future production.</li>
    <li><em>Send clear demand signals</em> via long-term target and volume commitments, such as by announcing target developments in offshore wind to drive the upgrade of vessels.</li>
    <li><em>Attract and retain workers</em> from the European Union and beyond by conducting early outreach in schools and offering targeted reskilling programs.</li>
    <li><em>Reduce labor demand</em> through automation and digitalization.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Potential actions for other stakeholders</h3>
<p>Other stakeholders could consider the following actions:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Scale up regional supply chains</em> to a critical minimum; for example, use incentives (including both taxes and subsidies) or insert sustainability and local content criteria into tenders and policies.</li>
    <li><em>Encourage innovation,</em> including around substitutes for critical and scarce raw materials.</li>
    <li><em>Harmonize regulations</em> and streamline permitting processes.</li>
    <li><em>Introduce intra-European Union alliances to source strategic raw materials,</em> including rare-earth materials.</li>
    <li><em>Increase OEM recycling of raw materials</em> such as aluminum, lithium, and cobalt by creating financial incentives and setting standards regarding higher levels of reuse.</li>
    <li><em>Communicate and commit</em> on growth plans to build the confidence that will allow businesses to make proactive investments.</li>
    <li><em>Invest in labor programs</em> for blue-collar energy transition jobs focused on metallurgy and RES manufacturing capabilities. Programs could include skilling and reskilling while also facilitating international and cross-sector utilization.</li>
    <li><em>Attract and retain workers</em> from the European Union and beyond—for example, by facilitating migration, activating passive workforce segments, and ensuring a predictable and steady project pipeline.</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p>The supply chains for crucial energy transition and electrification technologies are only as strong as their weakest links. Therefore, businesses and other relevant stakeholders may benefit from plotting out and mitigating potential risks along every step of the supply chain. This is a significant endeavor, but it is also a real opportunity for innovation and collaboration among stakeholders. Those that can build resilient, future-ready supply chains will be well positioned to reap significant benefits as the energy transition continues to gather momentum.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Stathia Bampinioti</strong> is a consultant in McKinsey’s Athens office; <strong><a href="/our-people/harald-bauer">Harald Bauer</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Frankfurt office, where <strong>Friederike Liebach</strong> is a consultant; <strong>Nadia Christakou</strong> is an associate partner in the Geneva office, where <strong>Luigi Gigliotti</strong> is an associate partner; <strong><a href="/our-people/lorenzo-moavero-milanesi">Lorenzo Moavero Milanesi</a></strong> is a partner in the Milan office; <strong><a href="/our-people/humayun-tai">Humayun Tai</a></strong> is a senior partner in the New York office; and <strong><a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b1f1fbafa-dff3-4c0a-8266-79f3ad6e78c4%7d%40en">Raffael Winter</a></strong> is a partner in the Düsseldorf office, where <strong>Emil Hosius</strong> is a consultant.</p>
<p>This article represents views from McKinsey’s Advanced Industries and Electric Power & Natural Gas Practices and McKinsey’s initiatives on orderly energy transition and industrial electrification.</p>

id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Building resilient supply chains for the European energy transition","displayName":"Building resilient supply chains for the European energy transition","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"671e01a6-1a18-4433-bf99-dafffeedf1e5","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Building resilient supply chains for the European energy transition"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Building supply chains for energy transition"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"To ensure a timely and orderly energy transition, companies and other\u0026nbsp;stakeholders urgently need to strengthen each step of the already-stretched supply chains of key technologies."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"To ensure a timely and orderly energy transition, companies and stakeholders urgently need to strengthen each step of the supply chains of key technologies."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-10-17T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIn earlier research\u003c/strong\u003e on solving the net-zero equation,[[footnote 1]] we described the nine key requirements we believe must be met for an orderly energy transition. These fall into three broad categories: physical building blocks; economic and societal adjustments; and governance, institutions, and commitments. This article focuses on the first area, particularly on the ability to create at-scale supply chains and support infrastructure for key decarbonization technologies.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar authors]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe energy transition is already well under way in Europe, but it will need to accelerate significantly to meet the European Union\u0026rsquo;s Fit for 55 targets and deliver on REPowerEU, an energy security action plan developed in response to events in Ukraine.[[footnote 2]] One measure in the REPowerEU plan, for example, mandates the installation of 320 gigawatts (GW) of new solar photovoltaics (PVs) by 2025 and 600 GW by 2030. Meeting this goal will require a threefold to fivefold increase in the solar PV installation rate.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eIncreased (and increasing) demand for the technologies that enable decarbonization\u0026mdash;such as electrification technologies across industrial processes, buildings, power supply, and the mobility industry\u0026mdash;creates many knock-on opportunities. Companies at each step of the affected value chain have the opportunity to benefit, as we discussed in a recent article focused on electrification.[[footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThose looking to take advantage of these opportunities will need to be cognizant of a number of risks and act to avoid them. Avoiding bottlenecks in already-stretched supply chains is particularly important, especially in the context of recent geopolitical events; bottlenecks create risks around volume shortages, price volatility, geographical-sourcing dependency, long lead times, and issues with quality. These risks can affect all key energy transition technologies and every step of the supply chain. Particular challenges are expected around the procurement of raw materials, manufacturing of components, and availability of labor for construction and installation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBusinesses and other key stakeholders looking to shore up supply chain resilience for an orderly energy transition can take a range of mitigation actions. Fast and decisive action to analyze and strengthen supply chains and a willingness to invest judiciously can help position Europe and its businesses to capture the substantial opportunities of an orderly energy transition. A lack of action will increase the risk that Europe may fall behind in achieving its important, ambitious energy goals\u0026mdash;or even miss out on these opportunities entirely.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe energy transition is under way, and the pace of decarbonization will only increase\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe drive toward decarbonization, increasing cost competitiveness, and geopolitical considerations have further accelerated the energy transition and significantly increased the pace of electrification.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut the rate of decarbonization will need to more than triple to meet the European Union\u0026rsquo;s Fit for 55 target of a 55 percent emissions reduction from 1990 levels by 2030.[[footnote 4]] There will need to be a dramatic shift toward renewables in power supply and toward electrification technologies in demand.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese top-level targets have profound implications for the products and technologies that enable electrification and thus decarbonization. Renewable-energy sources (RES), for example, will need to constitute 70 percent of the generation mix by 2030.[[footnote 5]] Increased demand for electricity will further complicate the transition.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe result of these shifts will be a strong and growing demand for electrification-enabling technologies. These technologies include wind, solar PV, and battery storage in the power industry; heat pumps for buildings and industrial processes; and batteries and charging infrastructure for the mobility sector, to name just a few. This burgeoning demand will be synchronized along the entire value chain, from raw and processed materials and manufacturing of components and assemblies all the way to logistics and construction.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eSupply chains are facing significant\u0026mdash;and growing\u0026mdash;challenges\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSupply chains for key energy transition technologies are already stretched, and recent geopolitical events have further exacerbated the situation. The global pandemic disrupted supply chains, resulting in multiple-month production halts while major supplier countries went into lockdown.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor example, more than two years into the pandemic, the gap between chip supply and demand has widened across all semiconductor-enabled products. This semiconductor shortage will likely persist in selected technology nodes for the next three to five years. For mature node sizes, for example, shortages are expected to persist until 2026.[[footnote 6]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMore recently, the war in Ukraine has disrupted the supply of oil and gas and has driven many European countries to make decisions that will have a long-term impact on where and how they source their energy supply. There have also been disruptions around other key raw materials for which Russia and Ukraine are key suppliers. For example, 43 percent of the global production of palladium is sourced from Russia, 33 percent of global semifinished steel imports are supplied by Russia or Ukraine, and 17 percent of global class 1 nickel is produced in Russia.[[footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese events and trends could amplify five risk areas related to supply chains: volume shortage, price volatility, geographical-sourcing dependency, long lead times, and issues with quality (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eKey industry players are increasingly aware of the need to act\u0026mdash;and many have already started to do so. In 2022, for example, the World Economic Forum noted the risk of choke points in the supply of commodities such as lithium and copper and advocated for global standards as well as increased innovation to boost supply diversity.[[footnote 8]] In September 2021, the European Raw Materials Alliance introduced a plan calling for governments and manufacturers to support mining and processing through a mix of subsidies and sales quotas.[[footnote 9]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRisks exist along each step of the supply chain\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSupply chain risks can affect procurement, manufacturing, logistics, and construction. These risks have the potential to cause serious disruption for all key energy transition technologies (Exhibit 2). For a deep dive on how supply chain risks threaten every step of the value chain for heat pumps, see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;Vulnerabilities in the heat pump supply chain.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eIndividual risk profiles and the actions needed to minimize them vary for each step of the value chain, with particular challenges expected in raw materials, components, and labor.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003ch3\u003eProcurement of raw and processed materials\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe main supply chain risks that are likely to affect raw materials are supply shortages and geographical-sourcing dependency.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese risks will be particularly severe for rare-earth materials. Neodymium and praseodymium, for example, are key components of the permanent magnets used in wind power and electric vehicles (EVs) and will see a surge in demand in the coming years. Substitution options are limited, which may create risks in the future because the industry is highly dependent on China\u0026rsquo;s refining capacity. Recycling will therefore be a key focus area, but based on expected capacity growth plans, we nevertheless predict an undersupply of 50 to 60 percent in 2030, leading to significant price spikes.[[footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther raw materials will also be affected. For example, the energy transition and electrification will significantly increase demand for metals such as nickel, lithium, cobalt, aluminum, and copper. Demand is already rising, which has driven price increases (Exhibit 3). We expect that opportunities for increasing supply, recycling, and substitution will maintain a relative equilibrium between supply and demand for aluminum, copper, and cobalt, but we expect to see supply shortages of class 1 nickel and lithium in 2025.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003ch3\u003eComponent manufacturing and assembly\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIncreased demand for assets will increase demand for components, but the share of components that are made in Europe is decreasing. Dependency on non-EU countries for the sourcing of key components could therefore become a major risk, particularly for solar PV, batteries, and power electronics.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChina is (and is set to remain) the dominant producer along the value chain; it currently provides more than 70 percent of solar-cell and module components and 66 percent of finished lithium batteries.[[footnote 11]] Most semiconductors are also produced in Asia\u0026mdash;22 percent in China, 19 percent in Taiwan, 17 percent in Korea, and 16 percent in Japan\u0026mdash;with France and Germany together accounting for only 5 percent of global front-end production.[[footnote 12]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe steady decrease in the number of domestic EU production facilities for many components has mainly been driven by commoditization, which has led to competition based predominantly on price with few opportunities for product differentiation. European companies will struggle to compete on price; solar PV module costs are currently 20 to 35 percent higher in Europe than in China, primarily driven by higher costs for labor, materials, and CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e.[[footnote 13]] Scaling the local manufacturing ecosystem could decrease price differences by eight to 17 percentage points, but this will take at least three to five years (Exhibit 4).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eWestern turbine manufacturers dominate the European market for wind power. In the past several years, however, Western OEMs have faced profitability issues due to lower-than-expected build-out and increased price competition driven by a shift to purely cost-driven tender design in many countries. As a result, many European countries\u0026mdash;including Denmark, Germany, and Spain\u0026mdash;have experienced job losses and factory closures.[[footnote 14]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMore recently, rising commodity prices have further eroded profitability. Many OEMs are fully exposed to increasing prices, resulting in double-digit negative EBIT margins for some European OEMs in the first quarter of 2022.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Western world should build on learnings from the solar industry and strive to maintain a strong domestic industry and supply chain. As an example, refining tender designs to also incorporate more qualitative criteria\u0026mdash;such as sustainability, carbon footprints, and system integration\u0026mdash;could help ease pressure on the wind supply chain.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eLogistics\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are also risks to an orderly energy transition related to the transportation of key technologies to the location of installation. These risks generally manifest as volume shortages.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLogistics is likely to become increasingly challenging in offshore wind. Increases in both capacity installation and, as a result of rapid technological advancement, turbine size are likely to lead to a shortage of appropriate installation vessels starting in 2025. We project that in 2026, about three GW of planned capacity will not be able to be installed because of the undersupply, and the size of this gap will increase over time.[[footnote 15]] The lead time for supersized installation vessels is considerable, which means that without prompt action, this mismatch between supply and demand is likely to be of considerable duration.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eConstruction and labor\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSkilled labor to work on RES in the European Union is already scarce today, and employers experience a high level of competition from adjacent sectors. In 2019, for example, there were 1.8 job vacancies in Germany for every unemployed energy technician.[[footnote 16]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis labor scarcity will get significantly worse: the demand for blue- and white-collar workers to develop and construct wind and solar assets in the European Union, for example, is expected to increase by a factor of between three and four by 2030 (Exhibit 5).[[footnote 17]] Labor shortages will be further exacerbated by an increasing demand for workers to operate and maintain these wind and solar projects; the lack of technicians is expected to be a particular pain point.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 5]]\n\u003ch2\u003eStakeholders can act to minimize supply chain risks\u0026mdash;and seize the opportunities\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBusinesses and other relevant stakeholders could take a range of mitigation actions to guard against supply chain risks. These actions are not just about mitigating risk, however: building supply chain resilience can also be an opportunity and a catalyst for collaboration and partnerships, as well as a driver of innovation\u0026mdash;for example, to replace materials and increase productivity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePotential actions for businesses\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe right next steps will vary by the type and the specifics of individual businesses, but the following resilience-boosting actions can be beneficial to businesses along the supply chain:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDiversify and localize supply chains\u003c/em\u003e for critical raw materials and components across multiple suppliers and geographies.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eExplore opportunities for cross-industry pooled procurement\u003c/em\u003e of raw materials.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eInvest in recycling, innovation, and research around substitutes\u003c/em\u003e for critical materials.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eExplore opportunities for vertical integration\u003c/em\u003e to secure critical raw materials and decrease price volatility, either through alliances and partnerships or through targeted acquisitions.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eOptimize procurement strategies\u003c/em\u003e by targeting long-term supply agreements or developing streaming agreements with advance lump-sum payments for future production.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eSend clear demand signals\u003c/em\u003e via long-term target and volume commitments, such as by announcing target developments in offshore wind to drive the upgrade of vessels.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAttract and retain workers\u003c/em\u003e from the European Union and beyond by conducting early outreach in schools and offering targeted reskilling programs.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eReduce labor demand\u003c/em\u003e through automation and digitalization.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePotential actions for other stakeholders\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther stakeholders could consider the following actions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eScale up regional supply chains\u003c/em\u003e to a critical minimum; for example, use incentives (including both taxes and subsidies) or insert sustainability and local content criteria into tenders and policies.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEncourage innovation,\u003c/em\u003e including around substitutes for critical and scarce raw materials.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eHarmonize regulations\u003c/em\u003e and streamline permitting processes.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIntroduce intra-European Union alliances to source strategic raw materials,\u003c/em\u003e including rare-earth materials.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIncrease OEM recycling of raw materials\u003c/em\u003e such as aluminum, lithium, and cobalt by creating financial incentives and setting standards regarding higher levels of reuse.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCommunicate and commit\u003c/em\u003e on growth plans to build the confidence that will allow businesses to make proactive investments.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eInvest in labor programs\u003c/em\u003e for blue-collar energy transition jobs focused on metallurgy and RES manufacturing capabilities. Programs could include skilling and reskilling while also facilitating international and cross-sector utilization.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAttract and retain workers\u003c/em\u003e from the European Union and beyond\u0026mdash;for example, by facilitating migration, activating passive workforce segments, and ensuring a predictable and steady project pipeline.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe supply chains for crucial energy transition and electrification technologies are only as strong as their weakest links. Therefore, businesses and other relevant stakeholders may benefit from plotting out and mitigating potential risks along every step of the supply chain. This is a significant endeavor, but it is also a real opportunity for innovation and collaboration among stakeholders. current on your favorite topics"}}}]},"articlesidebar":{"results":[{"mediaID":{"value":"1"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHeat pumps can be used\u003c/strong\u003e to electrify both space and water heating in the residential- and commercial-buildings sector, where they replace gas and oil boilers. They can also be used to electrify industrial processes such as in the chemicals, pulp and paper, and food and beverage industries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHistorically, heat pumps have been significantly more expensive than alternatives in terms of total cost of ownership. At 2019 fuel prices, for example, the cost of heating an average German residential dwelling was about 50 percent higher with air-to-water heat pumps than with a condensing gas boiler.[[footnote 1]] However, rising commodity prices and direct subsidies are rendering these pumps increasingly cost competitive. In addition, carbon taxes and policies will further encourage the installation of heat pumps, which are both a short-term lever to reduce European dependency on Russian oil and gas and a key longer-term decarbonization lever.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs a result, the European Commission has set a target to double the rate of deployment of heat pumps over the next five years. [[footnote 2]] An analysis of heat pump supply chains, however, reveals a number of potential vulnerabilities:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eProcurement of raw and processed material.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e Steel and copper are among the key raw materials for the creation of heat pumps. While steel production will likely not face bottlenecks in supply, increased demand for green steel and increasing energy prices might significantly drive up steel prices. There will also likely be a near-term undersupply of copper. Demand will increase as a result of grid expansion, increasing renewable energy, and the adoption of electric vehicles (EVs), while supply will be limited by aging mining assets and weak project pipelines.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eComponent manufacturing.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e While components such as fans and valves are highly commoditized, and therefore no sourcing constraints are expected, inverters and electrical components may fall victim to the semiconductor bottleneck.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eComponents assembly.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e Increased use can increase the output of existing assembly lines, but there are high barriers to entry for new players in the heat pump market; complex systems and licensing requirements in certain cases result in a lead time of up to 12 months to open new plants.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eConstruction and labor.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e While increasing worker shifts can provide some labor scale-up flexibility, labor shortages might slow down the uptake of heat pumps. To meet governmental targets, for example, the United Kingdom will need to add 5,000 to 7,000 heat pump installers per year from 2025 until 2035.[[footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFurthermore, the ability to retrofit heat pumps into existing buildings is restricted by space limitations in urban housing and bureaucratic hurdles, such as the need for owner communities’ approval and preservation orders.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEnabling strong heat pump uptake may therefore require businesses and other relevant stakeholders to consider the following actions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdvocate for supportive policies (including subsidies and carbon taxes), launch awareness campaigns to increase local demand, and engage in large-scale skilling and reskilling efforts for technicians.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMake corporate commitments in commercial real estate to accelerate the adoption of heat pumps in stakeholders’ building portfolios.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCreate innovative designs to enable the retrofitting of buildings and allow for heat pump installation in small urban apartments.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eScale up assembly-line production capacity with a focus on automated-manufacturing practices.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Vulnerabilities in the heat pump supply
